column4: [repost due to disconnect] I have four or five Ubuntu boxes running precise behind a slow link.  I'd like to download stuff like nvidia-current only once if possible.  What's the best way to do this in an automated fashion?
download the packages to a local machine, and setup your own repo
is there an automated way to do that?
not really no
you just download the packages you want from repository you are using (its just a http server)
okay, so there's no automated solution.  I find that really surprising, as what I want to do is just the junior version of what a large site admin would do.
why would it be automated
it's just download the packages you want, and share them to the other machines
it's not exactly a tough task or concept to grasp,
I've been a sysadmin for a while, the difficulty here is not in grasping the concept, it's in desiring that the process run unattended.
it is unattended
you do it once, and it's done
then just cron it
for a sys admin of "a while" this is bread and butter stuff
It's distro-specific stuff.  When you start with System V Release 2.0 and VMS 5.5 and Novell, the newer stuff blends together if you don't use it.
the concept of downloading the files from the repo and pointing the other machiens at the downloaded server is not new or modern technology
again, yes, I agree, and I have agreed with you there.  I do not want to download them by hand, that's all I am saying.
just download the files you want, cron it if you want it to be automated/unattended, then setup your other machines (clients) to point at that central downloaded package list

you have a choice 1.) download by hand 2.) write a script using something like rsync to download the whole repo -exlucind what you don't want 3.) use apt-mirror to mirror the whole 60GB repo to your local machine
so far, apt-cacher looks like a fourth option which is wayyyy better than what you're suggesting.
if you think so, use it
I'm trying to finish the docs. :-)
